A product code is a standardized, unique human-readable identifier that is compact, and can be easily parsed. It consists of an entity code concatenated to a product specific identification string, separated by a hyphen. The format of a product code is: [EntityCode]-[ProductString], e.g., HANWH-Q_PEAK_DUO_BLK_G10__AC_365. A product string is comprised of upper-case letters, numbers, and underscores. Any character that is not a letter or number is a special character and will be replaced by an underscore. All letter characters will be upper case. To avoid clashes between identical product codes, an additional hyphen and an integer 1, 2, 3, ..., is appended, e.g. {ProdCode}-{incremental number}

Tilt is the angle relative to horizontal. Horizontal is defined as the x,y plane of a right-hand coordinate system where the the x-axis is East, y-axis is North, and the z-axis is vertical.

Roll is a right-hand rotation about an oriented axis, with a positive value being a counter-clockwise rotation. In the context of a solar module, Roll is the rotation of the module about the vector normal to the module's plane that is oriented towards the sky.
allOf.x-ob-usage-tips: The Roll element of Orientation is used when solar modules are installed on a slant.

Scope.x-ob-usage-tips: Scope is an element designed to allow Orange Button users to add context to the object it is included in. For example, if a user is trying to share BillOfMaterials information for a given Job, they would be able to share only the BillOfMaterials object and provide context by setting the JobID in the ScopeID field and setting the ScopeType to Job. By following this approach, users can narrow payloads to the specific target data while contributing the necessary context that allows the Orange Button Taxonomy to be so powerful.

This concept provides a cryptographically secure identity for a device and originates from the distributed ledger or blockchain technologies. The Cryptographic Key ID is derived from an asymmetric private/public key pair, typically generated on the device itself and stored securely, preferably in a hardware-secured environment like a Secure Element (SE). Private keys remain within this secure environment to prevent exposure. The CryptographicKeyID consists of a type identifier, the hash output of public-key-material, and optionally, a CRC check for error detection, ensuring uniqueness and integrity.

var.label: Volt-ampere reactive
var.description: In electric power transmission and distribution, volt-ampere reactive (var) is a unit by which reactive power is expressed in an AC electric power system. Reactive power is the power that is wasted and not used to do work on the load.

VA.label: Volt-ampere
VA.description: A volt-ampere (VA) is the unit used for the apparent power in an electrical circuit, equal to the product of root-mean-square (RMS) voltage and RMS current. In direct current (DC) circuits, this product is equal to the real power (active power) in watts. Volt-amperes are useful only in the context of alternating current (AC) circuits.

VoltageItemType.description: The voltage item type is used to represent a measure of voltage (the difference in electric potential energy between two points per unit electric charge). Unit source prefixes: num-us

FrequencyItemType.description: The frequency item type is used to represent a measure of the number of occurrences of a repeating event per unit time. Unit source prefixes: num-us

Energy_per_Duration.description: Flow rate, as Energy per Duration

TemperatureItemType.description: The temperature item type is used to represent a measure of temperature either in absolute terms or as a difference between two temperatures. Unit source prefixes: num-us

Cel.label: Celsius
Cel.description: A temperature scale based on 0 for the freezing point of water and 100 for the boiling point of water at 1 atm pressure.

K.label: Kelvin
K.description: The kelvin is a unit of measure for temperature based upon an absolute scale. It is one of the seven base units in the International System of Units (SI) and is assigned the unit symbol K. The Kelvin scale is an absolute, thermodynamic temperature scale using as its null point absolute zero, the temperature at which all thermal motion ceases in the classical description of thermodynamics. The kelvin is defined as the fraction 1273.16 of the thermodynamic temperature of the triple point of water (exactly 0.01 C or 32.018 F). In other words, it is defined such that the triple point of water is exactly 273.16 K.

F.label: Fahrenheit
F.description: Fahrenheit is a unit of measure for temperature defined by two fixed points: the temperature at which water freezes into ice is defined as 32 F, and the boiling point of water is defined to be 212 F, a 180 F separation, as defined at sea level and standard atmospheric pressure.

PressureItemType.description: The pressure item type is used to represent a measure of the force applied perpendicular to the surface of an object per unit area over which that force is distributed. Units include Pascal, PSI and Bar. Unit source prefixes: num-us

Pa.label: Pascal
Pa.description: The pascal is the SI derived unit of pressure used to quantify internal pressure, stress, Young's modulus and ultimate tensile strength. It is defined as one newton per square meter.

Bar.label: Bar
Bar.description: The bar is a metric unit of pressure, but is not approved as part of the International System of Units (SI). It is defined as exactly equal to 100000 Pa, which is slightly less than the current average atmospheric pressure on Earth at sea level.

psi.label: Pounds Per Square Inch
psi.description: The pound per square inch is a unit of pressure or of stress based on avoirdupois units. It is the pressure resulting from a force of one pound-force applied to an area of one square inch.

atm.label: Standard Atmosphere
atm.description: The standard atmosphere is a unit of pressure defined as 101325 Pa (1.01325 bar). It is sometimes used as a reference or standard pressure.

ForceItemType.description: The force item type is used to represent a measure of a physical force.  Units include newtons.

N.label: Newton
N.description: The newton is the International System of Units (SI) derived unit of force. One newton is the force needed to accelerate one kilogram of mass at the rate of one metre per second squared in direction of the applied force.

ElectricChargeItemType.description: The electric charge item is used to represent a measure of electric charge (the physical property of matter that causes it to experience a force when placed in an electromagnetic field)

Ah.label: Ampere Hours
Ah.description: An ampere hour or amp hour is a unit of electric charge, equal to the charge transferred by a steady current of one ampere flowing for one hour.

C.label: Coulomb
C.description: The coulomb is the International System of Units (SI) unit of electric charge. It is the charge transported by a constant current of one ampere in one second.

PlaneAngleItemType.description: The angle item type is used to represent the measurement of an angle. Units include radians, degrees and gradians. Unit source prefixes: num-us

Degree.label: Degree
Degree.description: The degree is a measurement of a plane angle, defined so that a full rotation is 360 degrees. In Std the degree is reported in a decimal format.

rad.label: Radian
rad.description: The radian is the standard unit of angular measure. The radian is an SI derived unit.

StandardTypeItemType.description:
Standard type for which a specific certification is applied. The UnitID format follows the pattern: document identifier, publication year, section of document, using underscore (_) as a separator. Some standards are published as multiple documents, e.g., IEC 61853 is published in four parts. In these cases the document identifier includes the part, e.g., "IEC61853_1", "IEC61853_2", etc.

More precisely the Unit ID is: {standard name/number}_{document part (optional)}_{publication_year}_{document section (optional)}{alpha sequence (optional)}. If the document part is omitted, all parts of the standard are presumed to be included. The alpha sequence (a, b, c, ...) is only used to create distinct Unit IDs where two IDs would be identical without an alpha sequence.

FailureMechanismItemType.description: Categories of failure mechanisms from ISO 14224

Mechanical_Leakage.label: 1.1 Mechanical-Leakage
Mechanical_Leakage.description: External or internal leakage. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Mechanical_Vibration.label: 1.2 Mechanical-Vibration
Mechanical_Vibration.description: Abnormal vibration. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Mechanical_Position.label: 1.3 Mechanical-Position
Mechanical_Position.description: Faulty clearance or alignment. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Mechanical_Deformation.label: 1.4 Mechanical-Deformation
Mechanical_Deformation.description: Distortion, bending, buckling, denting, yeilding, shrinking, blistering, creeping. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Mechanical_Looseness.label: 1.5 Mechanical-Looseness
Mechanical_Looseness.description: Disconnection, loose items. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Mechanical_Sticking.label: 1.6 Mechanical-Sticking
Mechanical_Sticking.description: Sticking, seizure or jamming due to reasons other than deformation or clearance/alignment. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Material_Wear.label: 2.4 Material-Wear
Material_Wear.description: Abrasion, scoring, galling, scuffing, fretting. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Material_Breakage.label: 2.5 Material-Breakage
Material_Breakage.description: Fracture, breach, cracking. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Material_Fatigue.label: 2.6 Material-Fatigue
Material_Fatigue.description: Failure traced to fatigue. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Material_Overheating.label: 2.7 Material-Overheating
Material_Overheating.description: Failure due to overheating, burning. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Material_Burst.label: 2.8 Material-Burst
Material_Burst.description: Explosion, implosion, bursting. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Instrument_Control.label: 3.1 Instrument-Control
Instrument_Control.description: No or faulty regulation. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Instrument_NoSignal.label: 3.2 Instrument-Signal
Instrument_NoSignal.description: No signal, indication or alarm when expected. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Instrument_FaultySignal.label: 3.3 Instrument-Faulty Signal
Instrument_FaultySignal.description: Signal, indication or alarm is erroneous, spurious, or intermittent. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Instrument_Adjustment.label: 3.4 Instrument-Adjustment
Instrument_Adjustment.description: Out of adjustment or calibration, or calibration drift. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Instrument_Software.label: 3.5 Instrument-Software
Instrument_Software.description: Instrument failure due to software error. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Instrument_CommonCause.label: 3.6 Instrument-CommonCause
Instrument_CommonCause.description: Failures related to a common cause. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Electrical_NoPower.label: 4.3b Electrical-NoPower
Electrical_NoPower.description: Failed power supply. Added to ISO 14224:2016 enumeration

Electrical_FaultyPower.label: 4.4b Electrical-FaultyPower
Electrical_FaultyPower.description: Faulty power supply. Added to ISO 14224 Table B.2

Electrical_Resistance.label: 4.5c Electrical-Resistance
Electrical_Resistance.description: Abnormal resistance. Added to ISO 14224:2016 enumeration

Misc_NoCause.label: 6.1 Misc-NoCause
Misc_NoCause.description: No failure mechanism found or identified. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Misc_Combined.label: 6.2 Misc-CombinedCauses
Misc_Combined.description: Several mechanism, none predominant. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Misc_Other.description: Failure mechanism is not in the enumerations. From ISO 14224:2016, Table B.2

Misc_Unknown.label: 6.4 Misc-Unknown
